page.title: 13Legends & Stories, Whitby 2.
page.content: Legend says that long ago,{Whitby}was overun with{snakes!}Whitby folk begged {St. Hilda}to dispose of the creatures. She led the snakes to the top of the east cliff, cut off their heads and cast them into the sea. Their bodies became {ammonite fossils}which are found in rocks along this coastline. {Caedmon,}the father of English sacred poetry, was a cowherd in{St. {Hilda's Anglo Saxon Monastery}on the east cliff. He could not sing well and whenever the harp was about to be passed to him he always left the room.One night he dreamt that an angel sat beside him and asked him to sing about the creation of the world. He made up his own song and sang it to St.Hilda the following morning. The abbess was very impressed by him. He became a member of the monastery and turned scripture history into verse.
